data.title: Remembering HISTORIC NEWCASTLE - Old Photos, Maps, even Stories . . .
data.text:
Squipper

· Registered

Joined Jun 29, 2012

·

2,255 Posts

The High Level Bridge was built between 1847 and 1849 and this was in the very early days of the development of photography.

Newcastle upon Tyne: a selection of the Earliest Photographs by Frank Manders, published in 1995 shows the earliest image of the area as being 1850.

The earliest I've seen is probably the same one with the steam loco on the top Newcastle side as a nod to Stephenson during the opening.

Steve Ellwood

· Part Time Contributor

Joined Jan 21, 2011

·

44,613 Posts

The earliest I've seen is probably the same one with the steam loco on the top Newcastle side as a nod to Stephenson during the opening.

Not too sure that the replica loco was placed there at the 1849 opening, always thought it was a later date? - I'm sure someone will correct me if I'm wrong

This is a photograph from Frank Manders book - Newcastle Upon Tyne - A Selection of the Earliest Photographs which dates from circa 1864 and is the earliest image that I've come across:

Steve Ellwood

· Part Time Contributor

Joined Jan 21, 2011

·

44,613 Posts

The earliest I've seen is probably the same one with the steam loco on the top Newcastle side as a nod to Stephenson during the opening.

This the one you were thinking about Steve?

Courtesy of the Tyne & Wear Archives Photostream on Flickr

016467:High Level Bridge, Newcastle upon Tyne c.1885

Type : Photograph Medium : Print-black-and-white Description : The c.1885 photograph shows the entrance to the High Level Bridge. To the left of the entrance is the Bridge Inn and to the right the yard of Robert Beall "Architectural and Monumental Sculptor, Granite and Marble Merchant, High Level Approach'. A board is covered with advertisements for the Newcastle Courant etc. On top of the bridge there is a model of the No. 1 engine.

Courtesy of the Tyne & Wear Archives Photostream on Flickr

016467:High Level Bridge, Newcastle upon Tyne c.1885

Type : Photograph Medium : Print-black-and-white Description : The c.1885 photograph shows the entrance to the High Level Bridge. To the left of the entrance is the Bridge Inn and to the right the yard of Robert Beall "Architectural and Monumental Sculptor, Granite and Marble Merchant, High Level Approach'. A board is covered with advertisements for the Newcastle Courant etc. On top of the bridge there is a model of the No. 1 engine.

That's the one! I thought I had it but couldn't locate it. Thanks for clearing that up Steve.

Further to ^^

Does anyone have any more information about the "Romans in the Newcastle area", that is not already on the forum, and is therefore is not listed above?

Roman history in this region is one of the most interesting historical periods, I feel.

.

An interesting 1929 Advert . . .

Over on the Old Adverts thread, there have recently been posted a lot of old Newcastle (and area) adverts from 1929.

They were all courtesy of the Catalogue from the 1929 North East Coast Exhibition.

One advert in the Catalogue that I did not post, is this one . . .

It is an interesting advert from a "Newcastle buildings" perspective, as it appears to relate to this famous corner site shown below in a series of photos and renders, showing what has been built on that very same corner site, since 1929 . . .

(1) The original C&A and BHS Building . . .

(2) The 1970s replacement C&A and BHS Building . . .

(3) The 1970s Building, getting a massive revamp by Primark in 2012/2013 . . .

.

Another image for the collection, courtesy of the City Libraries Archive Collection on Flikr:

021473:Northumberland Road Newcastle upon Tyne 1971

Type : Photograph Medium : Print-black-and-white Description : A view of Singleton house on Northumberland Road taken from Northumberland Street. On site of Olympia picture hall.

Does anyone remember the unusual "first floor garage" on St George's Terrace in Jesmond?

To access it you had to enter at the corner of the buildimg and drive up a curved ramp to get to the showroom.

Very unusual, I used to think.

I have just come across a photo showing the garage, in a book called "Jesmond Pool: Making a Spash, How Jesmond Pool Made History".

The Garage can just be seen on the opposite corner of Bayswater Road, at it's junction with St George's Terrace. The photo was taken during the long hot summer of 1976 . . .

Enlargement of the Garage . .

How the more 'conventional' use of the building, looks today . .

Image - Courtesy of Google Earth

.

Going back to the HLB / Bridge Hotel pic, anyone know what Bartletts Posting Station was?

.

That's the premises of Robert Beall the monumental masons and I suspect that it may have also been a drop off and collection point for parcels - Bartletts being the carrier?

DXNewcastle

· cogito ergo sum

Joined Jan 24, 2010

·

1,632 Posts

Going back to the HLB / Bridge Hotel pic, anyone know what Bartletts Posting Station was?

I certainly do not know, but the term "Posting Station" was sometimes used to refer to a place where people could place or "post" their announcements or adverts. (We all remember the phases "bill posters will be prosecuted" which gave rise to the jokes).

Looking at the position of he sign, then I'll guess that this was one such place, and that it refers to the large panel of posters beneath it.

DXNewcastle

· cogito ergo sum

Joined Jan 24, 2010

·

1,632 Posts

Does anyone remember the unusual "first floor garage" on St George's Terrace in Jesmond?

To access it you had to enter at the corner of the buildimg and drive up a curved ramp to get to the showroom.

Very unusual, I used to think.

Indeed I do, and indeed it was unusual.

When walking along St Georges Terrace, I would sometimes be quite concerned at the ability of cars descending cars at speed to stop before reaching the pavement. I seem to remember that it was associated with 'Routes Group' cars (Hillman etc) but in later years, the showroom specialised in one of the 'performance' brands (such as Alpha-Romeo or similar).

Newcastle Historian

· Moderator

Joined Jul 5, 2006

25,209 Posts

Indeed I do, and indeed it was unusual.

When walking along St Georges Terrace, I would sometimes be quite concerned at the ability of cars descending cars at speed to stop before reaching the pavement. I seem to remember that it was associated with 'Routes Group' cars (Hillman etc) but in later years, the showroom specialised in one of the 'performance' brands (such as Alpha-Romeo or similar).

You can just see the "Logo" on the first floor sign at the front of the garage.

It's a bit unclear, but can anyone recognise what it is?

Percy Trimmer

· Modern Antiquarian

Joined Oct 1, 2010

·

835 Posts

You can just see the "Logo" on the first floor sign at the front of the garage.

It's a bit unclear, but can anyone recognise what it is?

Could it be National Benzole?

Newcastle Historian

· Moderator

Joined Jul 5, 2006

·

25,209 Posts

Could it be National Benzole?

Yes, it certainly does look like that!

I can't remember what it actually was, but I'm 99% certain you are right Percy.

I was hoping it might give a clue as to the manufacturer of the cars being sold there in 1976, but it seems not!

DXNewcastle

· cogito ergo sum

Joined Jan 24, 2010

·

1,632 Posts

Yes, I agree with P.T.

It was indicating the brand of petrol, National Benzole, that was available from the pump in front of the showroom (and which is, I think, just visible in the photograph as posted above).

Manor Park School Years - 1965

Following the sucess of the FIRST ever "School Opera" last year (The Mikado) this years 'Gilbert and Sullivan' production was IOLANTHE . . .

Does anyone remember the unusual "first floor garage" on St George's Terrace in Jesmond?

To access it you had to enter at the corner of the buildimg and drive up a curved ramp to get to the showroom.

Very unusual, I used to think.

I have just come across a photo showing the garage, in a book called "Jesmond Pool: Making a Spash, How Jesmond Pool Made History".

The Garage can just be seen on the opposite corner of Bayswater Road, at it's junction with St George's Terrace. The photo was taken during the long hot summer of 1976 . . .

According to the 1968 Kelly's Directory this is the premises of George Jacques Ltd - Motor Engineers. Not shown within the group of business's shown as car dealers so perhaps it was for servicing and repairs only?
